text:
Hi I'm Julie Stanford and my superpower is 
designing technologies and experiences that people

love. I wear two hats. Half my time I'm at the 
Stanford computer science department where I teach

learners like you how to do research and design 
for technological change. The other half of my

time, I'm at Slice Bread a consulting agency I 
founded where I practice what I preach. Through my

consulting work I've witnessed many well-intended 
digital transformation projects with with low

adoption, lots of headaches along the way. Here's 
what I've learned from these failed projects. Even

though the term digital transformation sounds 
like it's about technology, turns out the secret

to success is to shift your focus to the people at 
the center. If you want to make sure that the new

technologies you introduce have long-term impact, 
you need to start with a human-centered approach.

We'll begin this course by taking a deep dive 
into interview techniques that you can employ to

uncover the true root causes of problems. Then 
we'll learn how to squeeze as much insight as

we can from that data. And finally we'll cover a 
systematic process for running rapid experiments

to validate your ideas and minimize risk at every 
step. Along the way we'll analyze case studies,

and you'll work through project-based exercises 
that will help you apply what you've learned.

What are some of the things you do at the 
beginning. Business leader Jonathan Alloy

will provide additional industry insights on how 
to plan, test, and launch an effective digital

transformation What you really have to do is 
step outside of your own preconceived biases

and truly listen. Be willing to follow up and 
dig and probe and ask why. My goal is to help

you up-level your career by teaching you how 
to use human centered tools to confidently run

a successful digital transformation project. So 
join us from wherever you are at Stanford Online.
